S2.T1.caption: TABLE I: List of key notations.
S2.T1.table:
Symbol Description
𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} The set of candidate clients
𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} Local dataset of client k𝑘k
𝒟kAsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝐴\mathcal{D}_{k}^{A} AIGC-enhanced dataset of client k𝑘k
Fk,Lsubscript𝐹𝑘𝐿F_{k,L} Loss function of client k𝑘k over its local dataset
Fk,Asubscript𝐹𝑘𝐴F_{k,A} Loss function for client k𝑘k over its AIGC-enhanced dataset
pak​(y=i)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑎𝑦𝑖p^{k}_{a}(y=i) Client k𝑘k ’s proportion of data samples for data synthesis
dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k} Data size of client k𝑘k
λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k} Parameter for data quality of client k𝑘k’s local dataset
λk,Asubscript𝜆𝑘𝐴\lambda_{k,A} Parameter for data quality of client k𝑘k’s AIGC-enhanced dataset
sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k} Data-computing cost per unit data sample for client k𝑘k
𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} The set of participating clients
𝒩Lsuperscript𝒩𝐿\mathcal{N}^{L} The set of participating clients using local datasets
𝒩Asuperscript𝒩𝐴\mathcal{N}^{A} The set of participating clients using AIGC-enhanced datasets
r𝑟r The uniform unit data reward benchmark r𝑟r
T𝑇T The number of global iterations
R​(𝒩r)𝑅subscript𝒩𝑟R(\mathcal{N}_{r}) Total payment to participating clients given benchmark r𝑟r
references: In this section, we first introduce AIGC-empowered FL paradigm. We further characterize clients’ attributes, clients’ utility functions and server’s utility function. Finally, we propose data quality-aware incentive mechanism under complete and incomplete information scenarios. For readability, we summarize the key notations in Table I.

references: As for the non-IID degree λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k} which is dataset-specified, we estimate the rough range of λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k} under different data partition cases. Specifically, for the data partition case where client k𝑘k possesses data samples from l𝑙l classes, we conduct a simple FL training process with T=20𝑇20T=20 global iterations and record the maximum gradient error between the local gradient of client k𝑘k and the global gradient, i.e., λk​(l)=maxt⁡‖∇Fk​(𝒘t)−∇F​(𝒘t)‖subscript𝜆𝑘𝑙subscript𝑡norm∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝒘𝑡∇𝐹superscript𝒘𝑡\lambda_{k}(l)=\max_{t}\|\nabla F_{k}(\bm{w}^{t})-\nabla F(\bm{w}^{t})\|. Following this way, we are able to obtain the series values λk​(l),k∈{1,2,…,10}subscript𝜆𝑘𝑙𝑘12…10\lambda_{k}(l),k\in\{1,2,...,10\} and calculate the rough range of λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k} for each data partition cases of MNIST and CIFAR10 datasets, as summarized in Table II and Table III.

We consider FL scenarios with K=30𝐾30K=30 clients on MNIST, CIFAR10 and GTSRB datasets.
For the experiments on MNIST dataset, the server’s parameters are set as γ1=105subscript𝛾1superscript105\gamma_{1}=10^{5} and γ2=0.01subscript𝛾20.01\gamma_{2}=0.01. We set λk∼u​n​i​f​o​r​m​(0,3)similar-tosubscript𝜆𝑘𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑓𝑜𝑟𝑚03\lambda_{k}\sim uniform(0,3) and sk∼u​n​i​f​o​r​m​(0,10−3)similar-tosubscript𝑠𝑘𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑓𝑜𝑟𝑚0superscript103s_{k}\sim uniform(0,10^{-3}) for each client k𝑘k. Based on the value of λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k}, we can find the number of classes l𝑙l for the data samples of client k𝑘k from Table II, and hence assign dk∈[100,300]subscript𝑑𝑘100300d_{k}\in[100,300] data samples from l𝑙l classes randomly for each client k𝑘k. As for CIFAR10 dataset, we set γ1=106subscript𝛾1superscript106\gamma_{1}=10^{6} and γ2=0.01subscript𝛾20.01\gamma_{2}=0.01 for the server, and set λk∼u​n​i​f​o​r​m​(0,2)similar-tosubscript𝜆𝑘𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑓𝑜𝑟𝑚02\lambda_{k}\sim uniform(0,2) and sk∼u​n​i​f​o​r​m​(0,5⋅10−3)similar-tosubscript𝑠𝑘𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑓𝑜𝑟𝑚0⋅5superscript103s_{k}\sim uniform(0,5\cdot 10^{-3}) for each client k𝑘k. According to Table III, we can find the number of classes l𝑙l for the data samples of client k𝑘k, and then assign dk∈[300,500]subscript𝑑𝑘300500d_{k}\in[300,500] data samples from l𝑙l classes randomly for each client k𝑘k based on the value of λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k}. As for GTSRB dataset, we set γ1=106subscript𝛾1superscript106\gamma_{1}=10^{6} and γ2=0.01subscript𝛾20.01\gamma_{2}=0.01 for the server, and set λk∼u​n​i​f​o​r​m​(0,10)similar-tosubscript𝜆𝑘𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑓𝑜𝑟𝑚010\lambda_{k}\sim uniform(0,10) and sk∼u​n​i​f​o​r​m​(0,5⋅10−3)similar-tosubscript𝑠𝑘𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑓𝑜𝑟𝑚0⋅5superscript103s_{k}\sim uniform(0,5\cdot 10^{-3}) for each client k𝑘k. In light of data samples with large number of classes (e.g., 434343 classes) on GTSRB dataset, to simulate the uniform distribution of λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k}, we assign dk∈[1000,2000]subscript𝑑𝑘10002000d_{k}\in[1000,2000] data samples with a random number of classes l∈[4,43]𝑙443l\in[4,43] for each client k𝑘k. The unit cost or payment for one generated data sample is set to sA​I=0.01subscript𝑠𝐴𝐼0.01s_{AI}=0.01 for MNIST, CIFAR10 and GTSRB dataset.

references: Fig. 17 and Table IV show the difference of server’s cost between complete and incomplete information scenario and the corresponding averaged unit data reward benchmark r𝑟r for the two cases. To reduce the error caused by randomness, we conduct experiments 101010 times and average the results for the two cases. As depicted in Fig. 17, when K≥20𝐾20K\geq 20, the difference of server’s costs between complete and incomplete information scenarios decreases with the increase of the number of candidate clients K𝐾K. When K=10𝐾10K=10, the difference of server’s costs between the two information scenarios is the lowest, since the server recruits clients with AIGC-enhanced datasets by setting r=ζ3=0.6238𝑟subscript𝜁30.6238r=\zeta_{3}=0.6238 in incomplete information scenario. In essence, in instances where the amount of candidate clients is limited, the introduction of AIGC-enhanced datasets serves to alleviate server’s costs stemming from information asymmetry. However, as the quantity of candidate clients escalates, there’s a rise in the presence of high-quality clients (exhibiting lower λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k} and lower sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k}). Consequently, the server’s reliance on generated data diminishes. Conversely, offering a uniformly increased r𝑟r to a larger number of clients which use AIGC-enhanced datasets will result in heightened payments to clients.
